choices.text: Pain in abscess occurs because of the increased pressure within the cavity.

Metastatic abscess occurs a result of bacteraemia

questions.text: Which of the following statement is incorrect about abscess ?
questions.solution:
• Abscesses contain hyperosmolar material that draws in fluid. This increases the pressure and causes pain.
  • B)Most abscesses relating to surgical wounds take 7-10 days to form after surgery. As many as 75% of SSIs present after the patient has left hospital and may thus be overlooked by the surgical team
  • C)Abscesses usually follow a puncture wound of some kind, which may have been forgotten, as well as surgery, but can be metastatic in all tissues following bacteraemia.
  • D)When the cavity is left open to drain freely, there is no need for antibiotic therapy as well. Antibiotics should be used if the abscess cavity is closed after drainage, but the cavity should not be closed if there is any risk of retained loculi or foreign material.

questions.text: A 84 year old was being operated for aortic aneurysm and had blood loss of around 2 litres within first 2 hours of surgery. Blood products transfusion was initiated. What should also be given along with blood products that can minimise the risk of SSI?
questions.solution:
• In long operations or when there is excessive blood loss, or when unexpected contamination occurs, antibiotics may be repeated at 4-hourly intervals during the surgery, because tissue antibiotic levels often fall faster than serum levels.
  • There is no evidence that further doses of antibiotics after surgery are of any value in prophylaxis against infection and the practice can only encourage the development of antibiotic resistance.
  • Rest all measures can help reduce bleeding however doesn't have any impact in reducing the SSI

questions.text: A 2 year old child came in shock post road traffic accident. All attempts to intravenous access have failed and an intraosseus infusion in planned. What is likely site for intraosseus access?
questions.solution:
• The intraosseous needle is inserted into the medullary cavity of the proximal tibia about 1-3 cm below the tibial tuberosity.
  • Obtaining reliable vascular access in an infant or child is an important task that often becomes the responsibility of the paediatric surgeon.
  • The goal should always be to place the catheter in the least invasive, least risky, and least painful manner, and in a location that is most accessible and allows for use of the catheter without complications for as long as it is needed.
  • The incidence of catheter related sepsis or infection remains a problem, yet should be less than 1% with meticulous attention to catheter insertion care and exit site management.
  • Intravenous (IV) access for fluid resuscitation and medication administration is obtained with two peripheral catheters, 16-gauge or larger in adults.
  • For patients in whom peripheral angiocatheter access is difficult, intraosseous (IO) needles should be rapidly placed in the proximal humerus or tibia (Fig.7-6).14,15 All medications administered IV may be administered in a similar dosage intraosseously.
  • Although safe for emergent use, the needle should be removed once alternative access is established to prevent potential osteomyelitis.

questions.text: A 4 year old boy presented with per rectal bleeding with heamoglobin of 4 gm /dl. There is no history of trauma.No history of straining at stools.There is no history of fever or upper gastrointestinal symptoms. There is no family history of rectal bleeding. What is most likely differential diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The 4-year-old patient who presents with a haemoglobin (Hb) of 40g/L will most likely have bled profusely from an ulcer adjacent to a Meckel's diverticulum containing ectopic gastric mucosa.
  • A technetium scan may confirm the presence of ectopic gastric mucosa.
  • Option a) Unlike in adults, malignancy is an exceptionally rare cause of rectal bleeding. In new-borns, the life-threatening causes are malrotation and necrotising enterocolitis, and in older infants and children, intussusception.
  • Option c )Juvenile polyposis syndrome is an inherited autosomal-dominant pattern and is characterized by the development of hamartomatous intestinal polyps. Patients with JPS exhibit a 10% to 38% lifetime risk of colon cancer, and the average age at diagnosis is 34 years.
  • JPS is clinically diagnosed when there are five or more juvenile polyps in the colorectum, multiple juvenile polyps throughout the GI tract, any number or juvenile polyps with a family history, or juvenile polyposis.
  • Option d )Patient suffering from Campylobacter Gastroenteritis will have the following features. Hence the condition is ruled out in this case

questions.text: A 62 year female with vague upper abdominal pain was found to have a 4x2 cm lesion in the head of pancreas with central calcification and radiating septa on contrast enhanced computed tomography. What is most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Option A) On contrast CT it usually appears as thick-walled large cyst; gland atrophy ± calcification.
  • Option B) Central calcification, with radiating septa giving the sunburst appearance, is a radiographic sign on CT in 10% to 20% of patients. With the advent of EUS, these features can now be better delineated.
  • Option C)The radiologic characteristic of an MCN on a CT scan is the presence of a solitary cyst, which may have fine septations and be surrounded by a rim of calcification.
  • Option D)The radiographic features of IPMNs on pancreatic CT scans may include a dilated main pancreatic duct, cysts of varying sizes,and possibly mural nodules.

questions.text: A 40 year female presented with acute painful swelling below the mandible, precipitated by eating. The swelling occurs rapidly and often resolves spontaneously over 1-2 hours after the meal is completed. The image of the condition is given below
questions.solution:
• The image depicts Acute left submandibular sialadenitis.
  • The most common cause of obstruction within the submandibular gland is stone formation (sialolithiasis) within the gland and its associated duct system.
  • Eighty per cent of all salivary stones occur in the submandibular glands because their secretions are relatively viscous.
  • Eighty per cent of submandibular stones are radio-opaque and can be identified on plain radiography.

The second most common cause of submandibular duct obstruction is stricture.

  • Patients usually present with acute painful swelling in the region of the submandibular gland, precipitated by eating (Figure 49. The swelling occurs rapidly and often resolves spontaneously over 1-2 hours after the meal is completed (meal-time syndrome).
  • This classical picture occurs when the stone causes complete obstruction as it is washed forward and impacts in the lumen.

    Reference: Bailey and Love 27thedition, Page number No 781

questions.text: A 42 year old male newly diagnosed case of Ca colon under evaluation complained of fever,swelling,pain and redness of the right lower limb since 8hrs.On examination his Pulse is 120/min.BP 90/60 mmHg,RR 24/min. On examination, crepitus is present over the right lower limb. Patient over a period of time developed a bullous lesion. Patient was immediately posted for surgery. Which organism is responsible for this non traumatic spontaneous onset Gas Gangrene?
questions.solution:
• The much rarer form of gas gangrene is the nontraumatic spontaneous type, which occurs in 16% of cases, and the etiologic organism is the more virulent Clostridium septicum.
  • Nontraumatic spontaneous gas gangrene is often associated with underlying malignancy or immunosuppression.
  • Specifically, the association of C. septicum infection and colorectal cancer is widely reported in literature.

questions.solution:
• A ranula can resolve spontaneously, but many also require active treatment. The traditional and effective way is to remove the sublingual gland, but it is not an easy operation and the morbidity can be significant.

questions.text: A 54 year old female presented with a neck swelling in the anterior part for last 6 years. on examination she is found to have 12x6 cm large mass in with retrosternal extension. Which of the following is the imaging modality of choice to detected compression?
questions.solution:
• Option A) USG :- This is gold standard investigation to determine the physical characteristics of thyroid swellings. There are a number of ultrasonic features in a thyroid swelling associated with thyroid neoplasia, including microcalcification and increased vascularity, but only macroscopic capsular breach and nodal involvement are diagnostic of malignancy.
  • Ultrasound should be used as the primary investigation of any thyroid nodule as a reassuring appearance mitigates the need for an FNAC
  • Option B) Flexible laryngoscopy has rendered indirect laryngoscopy obsolete and is widely used preoperatively to determine the mobility of the vocal cords. The presence of a unilateral cord palsy coexisting with an ipsilateral thyroid nodule of concern is usually diagnostic of malignant disease.
  • Option C)& D). Plain films have previously been used to assess tracheal compression and deviation, but the modality of choice now is CT scanning.
  • CT scanning is also useful if ultrasound has identified metastatic disease in the neck as it can assist surgical planning and also assess the superior mediastinum and lungs.

questions.text: Which of the following syndrome is not associated with phaeochromocytoma ?
questions.solution:
• Hereditary phaeochromocytomas occur in several tumour syndromes:
  • Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN 2): an autosomal dominant inherited disorder that is caused by activating germline mutations of the RET proto-oncogene.
  • Familial paraganglioma (PG) syndrome: glomus tumours of the carotid body and extra-adrenal paraganglioma are characteristic in this hereditary tumour syndrome, which is caused by germline mutations within the succinate dehydrogenase complex subunit B (SDHB) SDHD and SDHC genes.
  • Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) syndrome: those affected can develop early-onset bilateral kidney tumours, phaeochromocytomas, cerebellar and spinal haemangioblastomas and pancreatic tumours. Patients have a germline mutation in the VHL gene.
  • Neurofibromatosis (NF) type 1: phaeochromocytomas in combination with fibromas on the skin and mucosae ('cafe-au-lait' skin spots) are indicative of a germline mutation in the NF1 gene

Reference: Bailey 27thedition, page number 845

questions.text: A 42 year male came with pain in epigastrium radiating to back with h/o chronic alcoholism diagnosed with acute pancreatitis. However he pain in not settled on conservative management and a CT scan was planned what is the optimal timing of imaging ?
questions.solution:
• While ultrasound may show gallstones and can demonstrate an enlarged pancreas with peripancreatic fluid and inflammatory changes, the optimal modality is CT.
  • CT performed too early in the course of the attack, e.g. in the first 12 hours, can be equivocal and the optimal timing of imaging is 48-72 hours.
  • In mild acute pancreatitis, CT may be normal or may show an enlarged oedematous gland, but in more severe attacks other findings which should be sought include peripancreatic fluid collections, vascular complications such as arterial pseudo- aneurysm formation or venous thrombosis and necrosis either of the gland itself or of the surrounding fat.
  • Necrosis typically develops 48-72 hours after the onset of symptoms, and is manifest on CT as lack of enhancement of the necrotic areas.
  • CT with intravenous contrast is therefore essential to look for necrosis, which is potentially catastrophic particularly if it becomes infected.

Reference: Bailey 27th edition ,page number 212

questions.text: Failure of rotation of pancreas results in annular pancreas which results in vomiting by causing duodenal obstruction. which of the following is preferred treatment for the same?
questions.solution:
• This is the result of failure of complete rotation of the ventral pancreatic bud during development, so that a ring of pancreatic tissue surrounds the second or third part of the duodenum.
  • It is most often seen in association with congenital duodenal stenosis or atresia and is therefore more prevalent in children with Down syndrome. Duodenal obstruction typically causes vomiting in the neonate .The usual treatment is bypass (duodenoduodenostomy).
  • The disease may occur in later life as one of the causes of pancreatitis, in which case resection of the head of the pancreas is preferable to lesser procedures.

questions.text: A Lactating female presented with pain swelling and redness in the her right breast from last 2 days as seen in the image below. A working diagnosis of breast abscess is made. What is the recommended method of treatment ?
questions.solution:
• If an antibiotic is used in the presence of undrained pus, an 'antibioma' may form. This is a large, sterile, brawny oedematous swelling that takes many weeks to resolve.
  • It used to be recommended that the breast should be incised and drained if the infection did not resolve within 48 hours or if after being emptied of milk there was an area of tense induration or other evidence of an underlying abscess.
  • This advice has been replaced with the recommendation that repeated aspirations under antibiotic cover (if necessary using ultrasound for localisation) be performed.
  • This often allows resolution without the need for an incision and will also allow the patient to continue breast-feeding.

Reference: Bailey 27thedition, page number 865

questions.solution:

  • Glucose transporter-5 (GLUT-5) is the brush border fructose transporter, whereas GLUT-2 handles fructose transport across the basolateral membrane.

questions.text: 60 year old male, k/c/o COPD, presented with diarrhoea and mucus in stool with abdominal pain and distention and passing stools and flatus. He was evaluated with CECT abdomen and is shown below. Which of the following is most appropriate management of the condition?
questions.solution:
• Pneumatosis intestinalis is an uncommon condition manifesting as multiple gas-filled cysts of the gastrointestinal tract.
  • The majority of pneumatosis intestinalis (85%) are associated with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease or an immunocompromised state.
  • Symptoms in primary pneumatosis intestinalis, when present, usually include diarrhoea, abdominal pain, abdominal distention, nausea, vomiting, weight loss, and mucus in stools. Peritonitis is unusual.
  • No treatment is necessary unless one of the very rare complications supervenes, such as small bowel ischemia, rectal bleeding, cyst-induced volvulus, or tension pneumoperitoneum.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common form of pelvic ring fracture
questions.solution:
Type A

Type A are the most common fractures and are completely stable. They result from lateral compression, which causes compression fractures of the pubic rami or compression fracture of the sacrum posteriorly.

Type B These fractures are partially stable, and there is disruption of the anterior pelvis and partial disruption of the posterior pelvis. The pelvis can open and close 'like a book', but because the sacroiliac ligaments remain intact, there is no vertical displacement. Internal or external stabilisation is required. Blood loss can be significant.

Type C This fracture is completely unstable. Both anterior pelvis and the entire posterior pelvic complexes are disrupted and the disrupted pelvic bones are free to displace horizontally and vertically. In both type B and type C pelvic injuries, there is a high risk of associated abdominal injuries (bowel perforation or mesenteric laceration) and rupture of the diaphragm.

Reference: Rooks bailey 27thedition, page number 377
